Chief Complaint: hypotension
   24 Hour Events:

   Echo showed LVEF 35% with infero-septal, inferior and infero-lateral

   Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2108-10-16**], regional
   LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD and at least moderate aortic stenosis
   are present (low output AS). Overall LVEF has decreased.
   Cath @2pm showed: CI 2.1, Fick CO 4.41. LMCA is short with 90% lesion.
   LAD has 90% lesion at ostium with segment mid disease to 70%. LCx is
   proximally occluded. RCA is a very large ectatic vessel with multiple
   lesions to 80%. No intervention performed. CT [**Doctor First Name 213**] consulted and would
   not do CABG at this time due to pulmonary status. Got Lasix 80 IV in
   cath lab and put out 300cc. Lasix gtt 5 mg/hr, titrate to UOP
   300cc/hr.  Received lasix 40 mg IV x 1 with good response.
   .
   Spiked to 102, cultures sent, changed anti-microbial regimen to
   vanc/cefepime/flagyl. Wary of septic physiology in setting of
   cardiogenic shock.
   .
   Lasix increased to 10 mg/hr, received additional bolus of lasix 80 mg
   IV x 1.  Weaning vent.

   Imaging: 1. No PE.
   2. Extensive bilateral pulmonary air space consolidations and ground
   glass
   opacities. As the lung bases were clear on the study four hours prior,
   findings are concerning for aspiration and pulmonary edema.
   3. 6.5-cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. No evidence for leak or
   rupture.
   4. Abnormal perfusion of the kidneys bilaterally likely relates to the
   phase of enhancement and repeated contrast administration.
   5. Diverticulosis. No evidence for diverticulitis
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with apparent hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.
   - Restart vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to optimize
   respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG.
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial presentation.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers.
   - TTE as above
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - Surface echocardiogram today.
   - Hold off on lasix pending determination of etiology to hypotension
   (cardiogenic versus distributive versus mixed).
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - Consider right heart cath to determine filling pressures and PCWP.
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch.
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.
   - Calcium gluconate, insulin, D50, bicarb, and kayexalate.
   - Repeat ECG.
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis.
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - Increase minute ventilation as above.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF
   ACCESS: PIV
   PPx: Heparin SQ, famotidine
   Code: Full (confirmed with HCP)
   Contact: [**Name (NI) 4858**] [**Name (NI) 2747**] (niece/HCP) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10188**] (h), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10189**] (c)
   Dispo: ICU level of care.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with hypotension, respiratory failure, and cardiac complications. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient's condition has deteriorated, with worsening hypotension, increased respiratory failure, and cardiac biomarkers indicating possible cardiac ischemia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and decreased cardiac output may be caused by cardiogenic shock, which could be secondary to cardiac ischemia, heart failure, or other cardiac conditions.
2. Sepsis/SIRS physiology: The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated white blood cell count may indicate a possible sepsis or SIRS response, which could be caused by an underlying infection, aspiration, or other factors.
3. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure may be caused by aspiration pneumonia, which could be secondary to recent intubation or other factors.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels may indicate acute kidney injury, which could be caused by hypotension, sepsis, or other factors.
5. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's elevated creatine kinase and transaminase levels may indicate rhabdomyolysis, which could be caused by statin therapy, hypotension, or other factors.
6. Hyperkalemia: The patient's elevated potassium level may be caused by transfusion, rhabdomyolysis, or other factors, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or other complications.
7. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and hypoxic respiratory failure may indicate ARDS, which could be caused by aspiration, sepsis, or other factors.
8. Right ventricular dysfunction: The patient's elevated central venous pressure and decreased cardiac output may indicate right ventricular dysfunction, which could be caused by cardiogenic shock, sepsis, or other factors.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is critical, and he requires aggressive management to address his hypotension, respiratory failure, and cardiac complications. The plan includes:

1. Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix to manage volume overload and pulmonary edema.
2. Maintain a mean arterial pressure greater than 60 mmHg and central venous pressure greater than 12 mmHg.
3. Treat for aspiration pneumonia or chemical pneumonitis with antibiotics and bronchodilators.
4. Monitor cardiac biomarkers and consider cardiac catheterization to evaluate cardiac function.
5. Manage hyperkalemia with calcium gluconate, insulin, and kayexalate.
6. Trend electrolytes, creatinine, and blood urea nitrogen levels to monitor for acute kidney injury.
7. Consider right heart catheterization to evaluate filling pressures and PCWP.
8. Monitor for signs of sepsis or SIRS and consider antimicrobial therapy if indicated.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and consider telemetry monitoring.
10. Consider surgical consultation for possible AAA repair.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%,PEEP 18 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,
   LV appears to be able to handle increased wall tension, an encouraging
   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - TTE noted above.
   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry, sinus tach;
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.  Now resolved, pt
   requiring K+ in setting of significant UOP
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs -> cont to be elevated, stable
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes -> creatinine stable 1.4 on admission,
   now 1.8, also encouraging
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis. Now resolved
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - Increase minute ventilation as above.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening

   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%,PEEP 18 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,
   LV appears to be able to handle increased wall tension, an encouraging
   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - TTE noted above.
   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry, sinus tach;
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.  Now resolved, pt
   requiring K+ in setting of significant UOP
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs -> cont to be elevated, stable
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes -> creatinine stable 1.4 on admission,
   now 1.8, also encouraging
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis. Now resolved
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - Increase minute ventilation as above.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old gentleman with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department for hypotension and respiratory failure. He has undergone extensive testing, including cardiac catheterization, which revealed significant coronary artery disease, including a 90% lesion in the left main coronary artery and 90% lesions in the left anterior descending and circumflex arteries. He also has moderate aortic stenosis and a 6.5-cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Hypotension (SBP 70s/50s) with a requirement for intermittent levophed
* Respiratory failure with mixed respiratory failure (hypoxic and hypercarbic)
* Cardiogenic shock with decreased left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and pulmonary edema
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL
* Hyperkalemia with a potassium level of 5.2 mmol/L
* Leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 15.4 x 10^9/L
* Transaminitis with elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels
* Acidosis with a pH of 7.40

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely related to his significant coronary artery disease, moderate aortic stenosis, and decreased LVEF. Aggressive diuresis and optimization of his cardiac function are necessary to improve his hemodynamics.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely related to his mixed respiratory failure (hypoxic and hypercarbic) and the need for mechanical ventilation. Aggressive diuresis and optimization of his cardiac function may help improve his oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's AKI is likely related to his cardiogenic shock and decreased renal perfusion. Aggressive diuresis and optimization of his cardiac function may help improve his renal function.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia is likely related to his AKI and the need for potassium supplementation. Monitoring of his potassium levels and adjustment of his potassium supplementation as necessary are important.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is likely related to his infectious process or chemical pneumonitis. Aggressive antimicrobial therapy and monitoring of his white blood cell count are necessary to prevent complications.
6. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis is likely related to his cardiogenic shock and AKI. Monitoring of his liver function tests and adjustment of his therapy as necessary are important.
7. Acidosis: The patient's acidosis is likely related to his respiratory failure and the need for mechanical ventilation. Aggressive diuresis and optimization of his cardiac function may help improve his acid-base balance.

Recommendations:

1. Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg/hr to improve the patient's cardiac function and reduce his pulmonary edema.
2. Maintain a MAP>60 and CVP>12 to optimize the patient's cardiac function and reduce his risk of cardiogenic shock.
3. Continue antimicrobial therapy with vancomycin, cefepime, and flagyl to prevent and treat potential infections.
4. Monitor the patient's potassium levels and adjust his potassium supplementation as necessary to prevent hyperkalemia.
5. Monitor the patient's white blood cell count and adjust his antimicrobial therapy as necessary to prevent complications.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and adjust his therapy as necessary to prevent complications.
7. Monitor the patient's acid-base balance and adjust his therapy as necessary to prevent complications.

In conclusion, the patient's complex medical condition requires careful monitoring and management to prevent potential complications. Aggressive diuresis, optimization of his cardiac function, and antimicrobial therapy are necessary to improve his hemodynamics and prevent complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%,PEEP 18 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,
   LV appears to be able to handle increased wall tension, an encouraging
   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - TTE noted above.
   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry, sinus tach;
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.  Now resolved, pt
   requiring K+ in setting of significant UOP
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs -> cont to be elevated, stable
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes -> creatinine stable 1.4 on admission,
   now 1.8, also encouraging
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis. Now resolved
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - Increase minute ventilation as above.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with hypotension, respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, with potential etiologies including cardiogenic shock, distributive shock, and sepsis. The patient has undergone cardiac catheterization, which revealed significant coronary artery disease, and has been treated with diuretics, vasopressors, and antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 106/73 mmHg, heart rate of 117 bpm, and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 98% on a ventilator. The patient's cardiac biomarkers are elevated, with a troponin T level of 9.69 ng/mL and a creatine kinase level of 1099 IU/L.

The patient's imaging studies reveal bilateral pulmonary air space consolidations and ground glass opacities, which are concerning for aspiration and pulmonary edema. The patient's abdominal imaging reveals an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm, which is not leaking or ruptured.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin T, creatine kinase, and lactate dehydrogenase, as well as decreased levels of albumin and total protein. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and his sputum cultures are positive for vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac biomarkers are elevated, and he has been treated with vasopressors and diuretics. This suggests that the patient may be at risk for cardiogenic shock.
2. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and he has been treated with antibiotics. This suggests that the patient may be at risk for sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he has been treated with diuretics and vasopressors. This suggests that the patient may be at risk for acute kidney injury.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is on a ventilator, and his oxygen saturation is 98%. This suggests that the patient may be at risk for respiratory failure.
5. Pulmonary edema: The patient's imaging studies reveal bilateral pulmonary air space consolidations and ground glass opacities, which are concerning for aspiration and pulmonary edema.
6. Aortic rupture: The patient's abdominal imaging reveals an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm, which is not leaking or ruptured. However, the patient's condition is complex, and there is a risk that the aneurysm could rupture.
7. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's creatine kinase level is elevated, and he has been treated with diuretics and vasopressors. This suggests that the patient may be at risk for rhabdomyolysis.
8. Transaminitis: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, and he has been treated with diuretics and vasopressors. This suggests that the patient may be at risk for transaminitis.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, and he is at risk for a variety of medical complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-inch tall, 91-kg male who is critically ill and admitted to the ICU with hypotension. The patient has a history of possible dyspnea for 2-3 weeks prior to presentation. 

The patient's cardiac condition is characterized by severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 35%, infero-septal, inferior, and infero-lateral akinesis, and mildly dilated right ventricle with global hypokinesis. The patient also has moderate aortic stenosis with a valve area of 1.0-1.2 cm and 1+ aortic regurgitation.

The patient underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed a short left main coronary artery with a 90% lesion, a 90% lesion at the ostium of the left anterior descending coronary artery, and proximal occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery. The right coronary artery is a large ectatic vessel with multiple lesions to 80%. No intervention was performed due to the patient's pulmonary status.

The patient has been treated with furosemide (Lasix) to manage fluid overload and has received additional boluses of lasix due to poor urine output. The patient's cardiac status is monitored closely, and the patient is receiving norepinephrine to support blood pressure.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with bilateral pulmonary air space consolidations and ground glass opacities on imaging studies, which may be related to aspiration and pulmonary edema. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating myocardial infarction or necrosis. The patient's liver function tests are elevated, and the patient has a mild anemia.

The patient's medical conditions include respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome, aortic aneurysm without rupture, and septic shock. The patient's plan of care includes continued mechanical ventilation, cardiac monitoring, and management of fluid overload. The patient's disposition is uncertain at this time.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: Given the patient's history of cardiac catheterization and the presence of cardiac disease, there is a risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, and there is a risk of developing pneumonia, particularly given the presence of bilateral pulmonary air space consolidations and ground glass opacities on imaging studies.
3. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is a significant concern, and there is a risk of developing further organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury or liver failure.
4. Cardiac tamponade: Given the patient's cardiac disease and the presence of aortic stenosis, there is a risk of developing cardiac tamponade, which could further compromise the patient's cardiac function.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's fluid overload and cardiac disease increase the risk of developing acute kidney injury, which could further complicate the patient's care.
6. Liver failure: The patient's elevated liver function tests and cardiac disease increase the risk of developing liver failure, which could further compromise the patient's overall health.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning given signs of end
   organ perfusion including elevated creatinine, LFTs, and cardiac
   biomarkers.  Potential etiologies include cardiogenic shock or
   distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology, anaphylaxis in setting
   of receiving blood products, or medications.  Bedside echo by
   cardiology fellow in ED did not show decreased LVEF but with moderate
   to severe MR with unknown baseline, which if new could be the etiology
   to patient's symptoms.  In addition, volume rescucitation in setting of
   suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs and 3L IVF could also have
   caused volume overload leading to decreased cardiac output and
   pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.  SIRS/sepsis could be
   in the setting of aspiration event during emergent intubation or
   TRALI.
   - Treat as sepsis with EGDT for now. Maintain MAP>65, CVP>12
   (intubated), ScVO2>70, monitor UOP with goal>30 cc/hr. Recheck lactate.
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and pip/tazo pending sputum cultures. Can likely discontinue in 24-48
   hours when infectious process ruled out.
   - Obtain blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top.
   - Formal TTE in AM to assess for valvular disease, LVEF, and wall
   motion abnormalities.
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with apparent hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.
   - Restart vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to optimize
   respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG.
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial presentation.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers.
   - TTE as above
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - Surface echocardiogram today.
   - Hold off on lasix pending determination of etiology to hypotension
   (cardiogenic versus distributive versus mixed).
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - Consider right heart cath to determine filling pressures and PCWP.
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch.
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.
   - Calcium gluconate, insulin, D50, bicarb, and kayexalate.
   - Repeat ECG.
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis.
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - Increase minute ventilation as above.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning given signs of end
   organ perfusion including elevated creatinine, LFTs, and cardiac
   biomarkers.  Potential etiologies include cardiogenic shock or
   distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology, anaphylaxis in setting
   of receiving blood products, or medications.  Bedside echo by
   cardiology fellow in ED did not show decreased LVEF but with moderate
   to severe MR with unknown baseline, which if new could be the etiology
   to patient's symptoms.  In addition, volume rescucitation in setting of
   suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs and 3L IVF could also have
   caused volume overload leading to decreased cardiac output and
   pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.  SIRS/sepsis could be
   in the setting of aspiration event during emergent intubation or
   TRALI.
   - Treat as sepsis with EGDT for now. Maintain MAP>65, CVP>12
   (intubated), ScVO2>70, monitor UOP with goal>30 cc/hr. Recheck lactate.
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and pip/tazo pending sputum cultures. Can likely discontinue in 24-48
   hours when infectious process ruled out.
   - Obtain blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top.
   - Formal TTE in AM to assess for valvular disease, LVEF, and wall
   motion abnormalities.
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with apparent hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.
   - Restart vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to optimize
   respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG.
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial presentation.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers.
   - TTE as above
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - Surface echocardiogram today.
   - Hold off on lasix pending determination of etiology to hypotension
   (cardiogenic versus distributive versus mixed).
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - Consider right heart cath to determine filling pressures and PCWP.
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch.
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated

   - Calcium gluconate, insulin, D50, bicarb, and kayexalate.

   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male with a significant medical history, including hypertension and hyperlipidemia, who was transferred to the ICU from the CCU for hypotension and respiratory failure. The patient's current condition is complex and multifaceted, with several potential etiologies contributing to his symptoms.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac biomarkers are elevated, and he has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, which may have contributed to his cardiogenic shock.
2. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and he has a fever, which may indicate an infectious process.
3. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and he has a history of aspiration during emergent intubation.
4. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's lung injury may be due to aspiration, sepsis, or other causes, which could lead to ARDS.
5. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's elevated creatine kinase (CK) level and myoglobinuria may indicate rhabdomyolysis, which could be caused by statin therapy, trauma, or other factors.
6. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, which may be due to transfusion-related hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, or other causes.
7. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which may be due to AKI, sepsis, or other causes.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
9. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and he may require further evaluation and management to optimize his cardiovascular function.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Sepsis protocol: The patient is being treated as sepsis with EGDT, and his MAP, CVP, and ScVO2 are being monitored.
2. Respiratory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, and his respiratory status is being optimized.
3. Cardiac management: The patient's cardiac biomarkers are being monitored, and he is receiving ASA and atorvastatin to manage his cardiac risk factors.
4. Renal support: The patient is receiving hydration and diuretic therapy to manage his renal function.
5. Electrolyte management: The patient's electrolyte levels are being monitored, and he is receiving calcium gluconate, insulin, and D50 to manage his hyperkalemia.
6. Infection control: The patient's infection status is being monitored, and he is receiving antimicrobial therapy as needed.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to optimize his outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%,PEEP 18 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,
   LV appears to be able to handle increased wall tension, an encouraging
   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - TTE noted above.
   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry, sinus tach;
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.  Now resolved, pt
   requiring K+ in setting of significant UOP
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs -> cont to be elevated, stable
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes -> creatinine stable 1.4 on admission,
   now 1.8, also encouraging
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis. Now resolved
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - Increase minute ventilation as above.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF
   ACCESS: PIV
   PPx: Heparin SQ, famotidine

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU for hypotension and respiratory failure. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient's condition has been unstable, with episodes of atrial flutter and sinus tachycardia. He has required intermittent levophed support and has been on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, consistent with myocardial infarction. His ECG demonstrates dynamic changes, concerning for left main or proximal LAD ischemia. He has also shown signs of decompensated heart failure, with pulmonary edema and elevated BNP levels.

The patient's respiratory status has improved with aggressive diuresis and volume-cycled assist control. However, he remains difficult to ventilate, with significant auto-PEEP and breathstacking.

The patient's acid-base status has resolved, and his electrolytes are being monitored. His leukocytosis is concerning for an infectious process, and he is receiving antimicrobial therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, and his ECG demonstrates dynamic changes, suggesting myocardial infarction. This could lead to cardiogenic shock, which is a life-threatening condition.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated lactate levels are concerning for sepsis. This could lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation. Prolonged mechanical ventilation can lead to respiratory failure and death.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and decreased urine output are concerning for acute kidney injury. This could lead to chronic kidney disease and death.
5. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's elevated transaminases and myoglobin levels are concerning for rhabdomyolysis. This could lead to acute kidney injury and death.
6. Pulmonary edema: The patient's pulmonary edema is a life-threatening condition that can lead to respiratory failure and death.
7. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated lactate levels are concerning for an infectious process. This could lead to sepsis and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue aggressive diuresis and volume-cycled assist control to improve the patient's respiratory status.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, and consider revascularization if necessary.
3. Continue antimicrobial therapy to treat any potential infections.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and acid-base status closely, and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Consider transferring the patient to a cardiac intensive care unit for further management.
6. Consult with a nephrologist to manage the patient's acute kidney injury.
7. Consider consulting with an infectious disease specialist to manage the patient's potential infection.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-inch tall, 91 kg individual admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of hypotension. The patient's 24-hour events include bursts of atrial fibrillation/sinus tachycardia, which spontaneously converted at times. The patient was unable to obtain sedation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.3C, heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 118/69 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 6 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation is 100% on a ventilator with a FiO2 of 50%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure of 4 mmHg, and the patient has received 2,341 mL of IV fluids over the past 24 hours.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.9 g/dL, and mild thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 107 K/uL. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 192 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 102 IU/L. The patient's troponin-T level is elevated at 9.06 ng/mL, indicating possible cardiac injury.

The patient's imaging studies show diffuse airspace disease that has improved, but small bilateral pleural effusions are still present. The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows frequent runs of atrial fibrillation/flutter.

The patient's assessment and plan include respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome, aortic aneurysm, and septic shock. The patient is receiving ICU care, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and IV fluids. The patient's code status is full code, and their disposition is still pending.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is low, and they are receiving mechanical ventilation. However, they may require further support or may develop respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's troponin-T level is elevated, indicating possible cardiac injury. They may develop cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure, or myocardial infarction.
3. Sepsis: The patient has septic shock and may develop further complications, such as organ dysfunction or failure.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and they may develop bleeding complications.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and they may develop liver failure or encephalopathy.
6. Kidney dysfunction: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and they may develop acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Aortic aneurysm: The patient has an aortic aneurysm, and they may develop complications, such as rupture or dissection.
8. Pneumonia: The patient has small bilateral pleural effusions, which may be indicative of pneumonia.
9. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, and they may develop VAP.
10. Stress ulcer: The patient may develop stress ulceration due to their critical illness and the use of vasopressors.

These potential complications will require close monitoring and management to prevent or treat them effectively.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows -> done
   - goal Is/Os even today, ensure UOP > 50 cc/hr
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course,
   today day [**3-31**]
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today -> done
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%, PEEP 10 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down, will
   stop cycle
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,
   LV appears to be able to handle increased wall tension, an encouraging
   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - TTE noted above.
   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.  Now has evidence of
   a.flutter.
   - Telemetry
   - failed DC cardioversion yesterday, will attempt again today on 12
   lead
   - start amio in interim, 150 mg bolus, 1 mg/min for 6 hours, 0.6 mg/min
   for 18 hours
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.  Concern today with 9
   point drop in Hct.  Will repeat Hct, consider repeat CT abdomen
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control
   - CT CAP non-contrast, transfuse 2 units PRBCs today
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia- etiology includes heparin vs. consumptive, no
   evidence of DIC on exam
   -  will monitor, hold heparin for now
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.  Now resolved, pt
   requiring K+ in setting of significant UOP
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Resolving.  Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs -> cont to be elevated, stable
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes -> creatinine stable 1.4 on admission,
   now 1.8, also encouraging
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis. Now resolved, pt has primary metabolic alkalosis
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - decrease minute ventilation as able
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF
   ACCESS: PIV
   PPx: Heparin SQ, famotidine
   Code: Full (confirmed with HCP)

   for 18 hours
   .

   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia who was admitted to the ICU with hypotension and respiratory failure. He was transferred from an outside hospital and has been intubated since admission. His condition has been unstable, with episodes of atrial fibrillation and flutter, and he has required intermittent levophed to maintain blood pressure. He has also had episodes of hypoxia and hypercarbia, and has required aggressive diuresis to manage volume overload.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and decreased cardiac output may be due to cardiogenic shock, which could be caused by his underlying heart disease or the effects of his recent cardiac catheterization.
2. Sepsis/SIRS: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammatory markers may indicate the presence of sepsis or SIRS, which could be caused by a variety of factors, including pneumonia, UTI, or bacteremia.
3. Ruptured AAA: The patient's hypotension and decreased blood pressure may be caused by a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm, which could be life-threatening if not treated promptly.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and BUN levels may indicate acute kidney injury, which could be caused by a variety of factors, including sepsis, nephrotoxic medications, or hypovolemia.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be caused by his underlying lung disease, pneumonia, or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be caused by a variety of factors, including sepsis, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia may be caused by a variety of factors, including kidney disease, rhabdomyolysis, or medications.
8. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis may be caused by a variety of factors, including viral hepatitis, medication toxicity, or autoimmune disorders.
9. Acidosis: The patient's acidosis may be caused by a variety of factors, including respiratory failure, sepsis, or kidney disease.
10. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be caused by a variety of factors, including infection, inflammation, or medication.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to continue to monitor his vital signs, laboratory values, and radiological findings closely to identify any potential complications and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows -> done
   - goal Is/Os even today, ensure UOP > 50 cc/hr
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course,
   today day [**3-31**]
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today -> done
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%, PEEP 10 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down, will
   stop cycle
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,
   LV appears to be able to handle increased wall tension, an encouraging
   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - TTE noted above.
   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   - consider repeat TTE today
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry, sinus tach;
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.  Concern today with 9

   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control

   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with

   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T

   .

   - Trend LFTs -> cont to be elevated, stable

   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes -> creatinine stable 1.4 on admission,

   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
